abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Santiago Urban Transport
            Technical Assistance Project for Chile were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was low or negligible; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory and borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: in
            upper-middle-income countries, especially the ones with high
            technical capacity, Bank involvement in transport
            constitutes a true two-way investment. Accompanying the
            whole reform process, from its design to the solution of the
            launch problems, was highly instructive and the lessons
            learned from this experience are greatly valued among other
            Bank clients. In upper-middle-income countries, access to
            international experiences and flexibility are more valued
            than the Bank's financial resources. To successfully
            implement a Bank project in a country like Chile, the
            Bank's financial resources constitute little incentive
            and other elements must be in place. It is difficult to
            design a good results framework for a Technical Assistance
            Loan (TAL) or an institutional strengthening component. A
            TAL that accompanies a Development Policy Loan (DPL) needs
            careful planning.
